characters: MOTORCYCLE GOING UP INCREDIBLY INCLINED STREET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The VIEWER'S VIEWPOINT breathlessly GLIDES OVER a body of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOBBY VOMIT charges through what seems to be a typically- deliciously-trashed dressing room, barking into a phone headgear apparatus.  His wire rim glasses amusingly con- trast with his traditional rock star look of shoulder- length blond hair and red-tank-top-over-black-spandex. His pacing reveals a helicopter pilot in the b.g., flying the dressing room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wha-at!... No, no, I can't do it tomorrow.  I'm taping a Rock Against Drugs spot.  It's important to me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vomit savagely snorts into a vial of crystal methe. Behind him, a big blanket on a couch rises up, becoming a giggling lump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five minutes, Mister Vomit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, man... Don't worry, Johnny, I have it with me now.  I'll just put it in a little protection program. He can't stop us, man, no way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vomit rips off his headgear and looks to a purse on the couch just as the purse's owner, a cancer-curing beauty wearing nothing but an oversize I (picture of a heart) Black Vomit T-shirt, bursts out from under the blanket, sipping from a pink bottle of wine cooler.  Her name is ZUZU PETALS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peek-a-boo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Zuzu, didn't I tell you to lay off the coolers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zuzu giggles away as Vomit slithers down to kiss her. While maneuvering his lips, he reaches out to Zuzu's purse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The VIEWER'S VIEWPOINT finally GLIDES PAST the water OUT OVER a dam, where, at the base, are thousands of screaming fans.  A stage has been built atop the dam amid spooky industrial art design.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The helicopter, equipped with a warped logo and the words BLACK VOMIT, swooshes to a halt above the stage where a b is rabidly pounding away.  The chopper begins to descend upon a makeshift "backstage area" to the side of the stag

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vomit!  Vomit!  Vomit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holding Zuzu's purse behind his back, Bobby Vomit bobs ba up.  Zuzu takes a dainty sip from her wine cooler, babbli softly in a losing battle with consciousness.  Vomit open the purse and pulls a compact disc from his Spandex.  The cover reads Black Vomit's Greatest Hits and has a red number one on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I had this dream, right.  You guys were doing that song, 'I Love You More Than My Own Death,' right, when all of a sudden these penguins come on stage and tell the audience that I used to wet my bed.  And that I enjoyed it.  It was so real ... How 'bout a kiss, Bobby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (closing Zuzu's purse) Sure.  Babe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zuzu drowsily raises her head, eyes closed, and adorably puckers up.  Vomit tosses her purse smack dab into her face and lips with a bonk.  Zuzu reacts with a dreamy smile and curls into a sleeping fetal position. Vomit turns to stare out at his screaming fans and then down to the "backstage area," zeroing in on an eccentrically, but stylishly, dressed man in sunglasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man is JULIAN GRENDEL.  The SOUNDTRACK suddenly ig- nores the band to go into Grendel's mind where elegant CLASSICAL MUSIC is PLAYING.  He wryly murmurs to himself as the reflection on his sunglasses go from the screaming crowd to the landing chopper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vomit.  Vomit.  Vomit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The inner CLASSICAL MUSIC CUTS OFF as Bobby Vomit bounds out from the 'copter, a skipping Zuzu in tow. Vomit and Grendel exchange cold smiles.  Julian Grendel is deaf; the sound of his speech is perverse in an inter- esting way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice of you to drop by, Mister Vomit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't spank me, Mister Grendel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vomit pleasantly walks behind Grendel and then wields around, screeching into the back of his boss's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drown in hell, you deaf motherfucker!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grendel turns around with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sticks and stones...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I thought you couldn't hear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Robert (Row-bare), you're so predictable, I don't have to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vomit seethes off to a nearby roadie holding a big drum of goo, flinging off his wire rim glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's do it, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The roadie begins pouring the goo over Bobby's head.

dialogues.speaker: STAGE
dialogues.text: The audience explodes in a flurry of cheers as...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome, sluts and perverts, I give you, Black Vomit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby Vomit strolls onto the stage -- and he's on fire. Covered from head to toe by licking flames -- a heavy metal human torch. Two Roadies with fire extinguishers fo-o-osh out the inferno that is the rock star's body.  Another roadie tosses him a mike.  Vomit smolders a bit -- transparent goo oozing over his body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly) Hello, L.A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd riots as the band breaks in with their question able but aggressively stated definition of music.  Bobby Vomit wails his way through a toxic first verse. He stops singing to spasm to his guitarist's solo.  He relifts his microphone and uh, he chokes, making gurgl- ing sounds as if something were trying to crawl out of his body. The crowd sounds like all ten thousand of them are in labor -- they love this. Julian Grendel takes off his sunglasses with a scared expression. Vomit's face turns red as he thrashes about the stage bashing down amps and barbed wire set design.  Vomit! Vomit!  Vomit! The band starts missing notes, looking around.  This doesn't seem to be part of the act.  Dribbling a crimson tide, Bobby Vomit falls to his knees with a final scream of earthly existence.  A final stream of blood rolls from his mouth down the white dam to the crowd who has reached a new level of frenzy beyond the limits of human comprehension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The VIEWER'S VIEWPOINT TRACKS DOWN a line of men and women standing outside the Rolls-Royce of nightclubs. The desperate-to-get-in crowd are dressed-to-kill-be- killed-and-kill again. At the front of the line, the overly rich and gorgeous thrust and screech over the velvet ropes as a stoic DOORMAN, standing before glass doors, uses all the zen he can to tune them out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You people are disgusting.  Don't you remember the Roman empire?

dialogues.speaker: RUCKUS AT DOOR
dialogues.text: The Doorman and the frenzied would-be patrons turn TO the VIEWER and go silent and motionless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Precariously-situated atop barstools are two very short club owners, JAIME and LARRY, dressed almost identically, looking out into their club.  A MAN IN A BLACK HAT, sitting between them, turns to sneer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So who the hell is this Ford Fairlane fuck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy's a rock star who don't play a note of music.  Carries a gun instead of a guitar... Am I right, Larry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasn't always a detective though, Jaime.  Started out doing every shit job in the biz; chauffeur, roadie, publicist, Phil Spector's bodyguard...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I wanted a biography, I'd eat a librarian.  What does he look like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like that...

dialogues.speaker: GLASS ENTRANCE DOORS
dialogues.text: Handsome and intimidating, the VIEWER gets their first clear view of FORD FAIRLANE as the Doorman swings open the glass door allowing a classical head-turning entrance into the state-of-the-art club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Spike, I was sorry to hear about your cat.  Those U.P.S. trucks are pretty wicked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you need somebody to talk to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford moves deeper into the club and lights up his seventieth cig of the day and takes in the la dolce vita ambience.  A band rocks out with an attractive, bizarrely-dressed female lead singer.  A mirthful CLUB GAL gets a look at Ford and stops laughing.  She pulls away from her suitor to slap Ford with a growl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You son-of-a-bitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa.  Another satisfied customer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Club Gal storms back into the arms of her suitor while Ford wiggles life back into his head. Ford scopes the tables around him.  His viewpoint halts at a man with red hair.  A BOUNCER breaks his concentration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford, I gotta ask you to put that out, dude.  Nobody smokes anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford flings his hand down with a quick motion and rubs at the carpet with his foot.  The Bouncer smiles and walks away.  Ford lifts back up his hand, revealing that the cigarette never left it.  He takes a drag with a grin until a hand slaps the cigarette into his face. It's the TWIN SISTER of the Club Gal who slapped him two minutes ago, in a different outfit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What goes for my sister, goes double for me.  Don't you remember the Jacuzzi, Laurel Canyon, the Guns and Roses video wrap party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling, coming back to him) Yeah, yeah... but you weren't identical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said you'd call us...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me give you my number, it's 555-6023.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks!  Wait.  555's not a real number.  They only use it in the movies...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford slyly walks off, holding up his arms to the decadence around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What in the fuck do you think this is?  Real life?

dialogues.speaker: AT BAR
dialogues.text: Jaime, Larry and the angry, anxious Man in the Hat watch on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Fairlane!  He doesn't look so tough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, just don't call him Mr. Rock-N-Roll Detective...

dialogues.speaker: FORD IN THOROUGHFARE
dialogues.text: TWO DRUNKEN COLLEGE BOYS thwap an unhappy Ford on the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford Fairlane, Mr. Rock-N-Roll Detective!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let us buy you a drink, dudeski.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding back a physical response) You two loony guys, what are your names?  Neal and Bob?  Or is that what you do?  Tell me, are you driving home tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go-o-o-d... Don!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford shifts away from the College Boys and into a seat at the table of DON CLEVELAND, a suave and amiable black record producer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So many assholes, so few bullets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn, Ford, you're the most cynical man in the industry and that's not easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not cynical.  Can I help it that life is a disease and everyone's a victim. So you're producing exclusively for Grendel Records now.  Hope you're taking Julian for a bundle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, ever since old Jack Grendel died, Julian has got me into one yummy gig after the other.  Not only am I producing, he's got me in some lovely-bullshit-money-money executive position.  What are you looking at...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford is looking off to another man with red hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some redhead's been harassing that all-girl group, the Ovaries. Hanging out at their concerts saying he wants to rape and kill them and not in that order.  Cops won't do anything until he actually does something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A killer-cute nymph, MELODI, in a tight-tight dress bubbles up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're that guy, the private eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a poet and didn't know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you really know everybody in the industry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only on a first name basis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's cute.  You're funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's funny, you're cute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard that Bobby Vomit O.D.'d, right?  Do you suspect foul play and stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you when somebody pays me to give a shit and stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melodi sweetly hands Ford a napkin with her phone number on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name's Melodi, as in 'a pretty girl is like a.'  Whatever you're doing tomorrow... cancel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melodi winks and walks off.  Don stares in awe.  Ford blows his nose in the napkin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta shave before you leave the house in a dress like that and I don't mean your legs.  Why didn't you jump on her?  What's happening to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I'm not interested in any club who'll have my member as a member.  Later, Don...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford scans to Jaime, Larry and the Man in the Hat at the bar. Ford stands and begins weaving between tables.  He looks to the attractive singer onstage.  Seeing Ford, she loses her place in the song.  She gives off a scowl to Ford and then continues singing.

dialogues.speaker: BAR
dialogues.text: Jaime and Larry see Ford approach.  Larry turns to the bartender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better have that vodka milkshake done.  Here comes Mr. Rock-N-Roll Detec -- Hi, Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bartender nervously pours a blenderful of vanilla milkshake into an ornate fountain glass and then adds a huge dose of Absolut, along with a maraschino.  He then lights the vodka shake afire as Ford reaches the bar, blows it out, and slurps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not thick enough, but better.  You're definitely getting better, Harry. (turning to Jaime and Larry) Hey, if it isn't Mutt... and Mutt. Who's your friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just some guy named Sam...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm just some guy named Sam, asswipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reminds me of that song by the all- girl group, the Ovaries, 'Some Guys Eat Reindeer.'  What.  A. Tune!  But what's that lead singer's name.  I'm drawing a fucking blank here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly very frenetic) It's Stuh -- Sta -- Sta -- Stac --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Man with Hat stutters like the fanatic he is, Ford casually knocks off his hat revealing weird streaks of red hair.  Ford smiles, turns to the bar, and takes a last sip from his shake before smashing the fountain glass into the face of the stuttering Sam, sending him off his barstool. The sleazebag leaps up like a wild animal and swings his fist at Ford.  Ford grabs onto the flying fist, stopping it dead.  Sam sharply swings his other fist around, but Ford grabs this one, too, locking them into an Arthur Murray lesson position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we da-ance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford heaves the fanatic into a nearby table.  The fanatic drops on all fours and crawls under the table.  A chuckling Ford strolls between the tables. Sam crawls out from under one table and makes under the long tablecloth of another.  The crowd has taken an activ interest, but the band continues to play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So finally got a tip that paid off.  Why can't you sleazebags who harass women take 'no' for an answer?  I mean, hey, it's never happened to me personally...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford lifts up the tablecloth.  The sleazebag fanatic is not there.  Ford bobs back up with a puzzled expression and puts a cigarette in his mouth. Ford brings out a lighter as the fanatic suddenly materializes behind him.  Sam grabs a huge glass candle holder from one of the tables and smashes off the end of it, causing a jagged edge.  The band stops playing as the CANDLE SIZZLES in Sam's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last... Dance... Mr. Rock-N-Roll Detective.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cigarette falling from mouth) Great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam the Sleazebag flails the jagged candleholder at Ford, who swerves away and connects with a savage kick to the groin, which Sam enjoys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam swings out again, but this time connects with a slash to Ford's chin.  Ford is more annoyed than hurt. His solemn anger stops Sam the Sleazebag in his tracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're ten seconds away from the most embarrassing moment in your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford launches a powerful uppercut that knocks the fanatic's candleholder-holding hand up into the psycho's own arm.  Screaming in pain, the fanatic flees toward the dance floor trying to pull out the shards.  Don pipes up from a nearby table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on Ford, this shit's getting old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford smiles, super-swiftly raising his arm.  A gun slides out of his sleeve through a sliding Taxi-Driver-style apparatus, into his hand. Ford FIRES up at a discotheque ball rotating above the dance floor.  The gunshot breaks the ball out of its ceiling home and sends it swooshing down right upon the Sleazebag fanatic's head, knocking him out cold. Ford turns to the approaching, awed twin sisters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clint Eastwood... I fucked him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The band cranks back up, echoing into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The swank nightclub a memory, the VIEWER is now given a jarring tour of Ford's lovable ratty beach house. The VIEWER'S VIEWPOINT MOVES UP TO a wall where a set of curtains mysteriously cover a compartment.  ACROSS the wall, the VIEWER sees hundreds of autographed photos of various rock stars pinned to the wall in a surrealistically haphazard fashion. PULLING OUT A BIT, it can be seen that the hellhole is packed solid with unwrapped VCRs, discarded gold records, answering machines, remote controls, Walkmans, Watchmans, cellular phones, and all sorts of other basically useless goodies.  Each one has a smarmy "Thanks Ford"-type note tagged to it. A tremendous music system adorns another wall with a pair of five-foot tall speakers standing like silent sentinels Embedded in one of the amplifiers is a wall socket timer clock -- two needles about to touch.  The TIMER, reading 3:59 p.m., WHIRS a bit and then there is a CLICK.

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC SYSTEM
dialogues.text: The LOUDEST MUSIC in the history of Dolby stereo BALSTS out of the speakers.  Dust is literally kicked up as a rollicking ROCK SONG careens through the room.

dialogues.speaker: FORD'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: The twin sisters pop up in the bed in various states of undress, their squeals of pain inaudible in the face of the music.  The lump in the bed between the twins jerks spasmodically for a second, then calmly rises, revealing itself to be Ford Fairlane, still wearing the sliding gun system on his arm.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: A ruffled Ford plods in and grabs a pack of cigarettes of a vibrating speaker.  He ritualistically lights up and inhales. Ford pulls back the curtains on the wall revealing a carved-out compartment in the wall.  Inside the space is an obviously old, but still in mint condition electric guitar with a picture of Jimi Hendrix propped next to it. Ford closes his eyes and touches the guitar with a religious solemnity. Ford pulls the curtains and then bends down to a red "Hotline"-looking phone with a quizzical expression on his face.  Ford picks up a remote control and zaps OFF th STEREO, revealing that the PHONE is RINGING.  Ford picks

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Jazz, I'm coming.  So I'm late.  I go to work when you go to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford hangs up and wearily rises.  A man who hates his life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Decked out wrinkled-hip, Ford closes the front door of his charmingly dilapidated home. THE KID, a spiky-haired surf punk ragamuffin in a multi- colored shirt over a Corona T, swerves up to Ford on a skateboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fairlane, you gonna find out who killed the lead singer of Black Vomit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, Dr. Watson, what makes you think he's not just another piece of shit overdose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford and The Kid, in an obliviously synchronized moment, flick out a pair of sunglasses from their breast pockets and put them on.  They then each pull out a cigarette and with a similar twist of the wrist, light it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gut feeling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give you a gut feeling, you little... Hey... hey!  Get that stick out of your mouth.  These things are killers, man.  Don't you go to school, listen to Smokey the Bear and all that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford tears the cigarette from the Kid's mother and starts to throw it away, but instead pockets it.  They approach Ford's dazzling blue namesake. Ford SQUEAKS off the CAR ALARM with a beeper and then opens up his unusually modulated trunk.  Sam the Sleazebag is seen huddled in a heap within.  Ford tosses a smashed-up Twinkie to him and recloses the trunk to frenzied screams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sick fuck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bone appetit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you going to let me work with you?  Why you always fucking with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why am I what?  Excuse me? (thwacking The Kid) I catch you saying the F-word again.  I'll kill you.  That's a fucking promise.  Now get the fuck out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford gets in his car.  The Kid boards around to the windo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got something serious to dis-cuss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well what is it?  I'm not Kreskin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid rockets off.  Ford watches with slight concern then tears off, MUSIC BLARING.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MINI-MALL DAY
dialogues.text: A two-tiered mini-mall nightmare looms ahead.  The exquisite eateries of SUZIE'S SUSHI DONUTS and MUY BURRIT are sandwiched in on the first level with a tanning salon and an adult book store. The top tier is not as popular.  Empty For-Rent spaces surround a place that has a big plate glass window that reads FORD FAIRLANE PRIVATE INVESTIGATOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford pushes sleazo through a door into his office. JAZZ, Ford's secre-uh-assistant, sits sharp and stern in a masculine business outfit and glasses behind a desk. Upon the desks rests a very respectable computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't prove shit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning she said as the clock struck five.  I sent the Ovaries down for food.  They've been waiting for hours...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your tip paid off.  Jazz, this is Sam the Sleazebag.  Sam the Sleazebag, this is Jazz, my secretary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Assistant.  And don't call me Jazz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All your friends call you Jazz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford chuckles and a romantic whether-they-like-it-or-not moment passes between them.  Jazz breaks it to look under her desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, IN X S paid today.  Their 'payment' is around here somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They paid?  I love Australia! What a band!  Let's throw a Foster's on the barbie and call up me mates... Cash or check?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) You wish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cash or check, Jazz?  Don't do this to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The OVARIES, four young women dressed in stylishly- shredded pink leather jackets, enter the office holding burritos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Ford, little late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's him!  That's the bastard. He flashed us at the Ampitheatre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you. (as Mr. Hyde) You sluts have no proof!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I could identify it.  It looked like a dick.  Only smaller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With an authoritative, silencing cough, Ford pulls a huge pair of hedge clippers from a drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could gab about evidence and restraining orders all day, but I think castration is really the way to go.  May get a wee messy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  (!)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford snaps his shears together with a giddy smile as the Ovaries move toward Sam, fiercely clutching their burritos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a new by-law for pathetic jerks who harass women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do we get to keep it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.  Every girl should have one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ovary One reaches down O.S. and pulls down Sam's zipper. Ford whooshes down with the clippers and slices.  Ovary One pulls up a half of a burrito.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next time, it'll be your burrito.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pure white Sam turns and runs into a wall, knocking himself out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I doubt he'll be hassling you anymore, but hey, I'll save the hedgeclippers anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ovary One takes a Rolex off her hand and gives it to Ford

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great job, Ford.  Take this.  As payment.  It's solid gold and it'll make sure you're not late for your other clients.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No really.  Money is fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great gift idea, Stace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Bye, Ford...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Ovaries exit, stepping over Sam.  Ford holds the Rolex like it were a cancerous worm.  Jazz laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do it for love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Bye Ford...'  Hey, let me cheer you up.  I found the IN X S payment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jazz pulls a live koala bear out from under her desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: G'day, they say it's worth three grand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking Australians!  I hate that country, continent, what is it? Don't we do nuclear testing there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's just declare war on the hellhole.  Before they make Crocodile Dundee three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rock stars!  I'm going out of my mind.  All I get are perks.  I don't make money, I make gifts. How am I supposed to pay taxes with bathtub compact disc players and autographed drumsticks.  I want cash.  Moulah.  Wampum.  Dead Presidents.  Andrew Jackson. Gerald Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're saying you need money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Car insurance costs money. Cavities cost money.  Doritos cost money.  I'm gonna eat that damn bear... come here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quit crying.  I think we've got a case if we can make it through the cavalcade of bimbos, here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jazz, using a remote, operates an answering machine on her desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (machine) Hi, this is Vikki, you know, Vikki. I figured you probably washed off my phone number before you had a...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sneezing) Bim-bo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut the play by play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This Chevy Nova?  Chevy Nova, there?  Huh?  Huh?  Johnny Crunch, K.O.D.S. (K-odious), you schmuck? You know the guy who had sex with your prom date before the prom and needless to say before he became the hottest D.J. in the West.  I gotta case for you, man.  Come down to the station about six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny Pinzolo calling himself Johnny Crunch.  Knock me out.  We grew up together in Brooklyn. Came out here to be rock stars... Of course, he's lying about the prom date thing, at least I hope he is, I took his sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (typically deadpan) You're friends with the most obnoxious asshole on the airwaves. The King of the Shock Jocks.  I'm, I'm shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, too, baby.  He wants to meet at six.  What time is it now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jazz dangles the Rolex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six.  Take it, you need it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PHONE on Jazz's desk RINGS and Ford instantly picks it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: K-O-D-S is going to make me rich!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He suddenly pulls the receiver away from his ear as PAINF NOISES blurt out of it:  SCRE-E-E-E!  BUZZ!  SHSHSHSHSH!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's for me... Radio contests, really Ford, how tacky...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brain-fried, holding ear) Ah -- ha... You know, you should think about dating Earthmen again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jazz takes the phone and puts it in a modem cradle -- two cups that fit over each end of the phone, all hooked up to her computer.  The horrible COMPUTER NOISES become nicely inaudible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what about this watch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep it.  It's your paycheck this month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford's Fairlane SCREECHES up outside a sleek building to the TUNE of a nasty teenybopper ballad a la Tiffany/Debbi Gibson. Ford bounds out of his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A needle is SCREECHED painfully across the tracks, giving the teenybopper ballad a painful death...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ye-e-e-a-a-ah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A RECEPTIONIST and a guard hold their hands over their ea until the sadistic SCREECHING ENDS.  Ford approaches as Johnny's anything-but-dulcet TONES croak out form a SPEAK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing like a tender ballad sung by a girl pretending to be a virgin. I'm sorry, young girls should not be out making records; they should be in, setting records making out. Naked.  On my coffee table.  Are you offended?  Well, slurp this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ROCK SONG spews from the SPEAKER...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here to see Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky you.  Arnie... Mr. Crunch has a lot of fans who hate his guts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arnie, the guard, slams Ford to the desk and begins frisking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Arnie, sometimes when we touch, the honesty's too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford moves into the station booth and takes a seated position behind his ranting friend, JOHNNY CRUNCH, re- vealed to be a sweating, scraggly monster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And don't forget, if we call and you answer the phone 'K-O-D-S is going to make me rich,' you could win a cool million.  Sexually transmittable disease jokes are coming up next hour so go get your mom.  Better yet, I'll get her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny punches some buttons and wields around to Ford, TURNING DOWN his MONITORS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe it.  Getting paid to be the asshole you always were.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking amazing, huh?  Chevy Nova, you Bensonhurst shit!  Still in La-la land.  Look at us, two rock 'n' roll dicks.  Unfortunately, only one of us is a detective.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice getting all those phone calls from you after you hit it big, you Redhook bastard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't remember any Arbor Day cards from Mr. Rock 'n' Roll Detective.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friendship's a lot different out here.  A wrong number is a relationship.  But then this isn't a social call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny pulls out a snapshot and gives it to Ford.  It's a picture of Zuzu from the opening scene, blowing Ford and the viewer a kiss.  Ford fondles it as Johnny gets up to pour two cups of Styrofoam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my daughter, man.  I know I never told you about her, but God, I love that girl.  She calls herself Zuzu Petals and she's been swallowed up by the gorgeous hell that is L.A. A fucking groupie partying with the pros.  You have to get my baby back, she's my pride and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Bye, Johnny...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead air, Johnny...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny grabs the microphone and squeals into it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you people leave me alone! I'm contemplating my life and you just won't stop listening!  Here's five in a row played at the wrong speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny punches some buttons and spins angrily to Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't take cases with foundations in bullshit.  They are very hard to walk around in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just find her, man.  She's my daughter, she's my sister, she's my mother, she's some little brat I stood in line with at Taco Bell last week.  Do whatever you want with my words.  And my money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny pulls out an envelope and opens it up to the soft sound of a CHOIR OF ANGELS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am told it is difficult to pay the phone bill with gold chains and V.C.R.s.  There's four thousand here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zuzu Petals.  Sounds like a drug. A lethal one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you solve the case and I know you will, because you're the best.  Ford, guys like you don't grow on trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny and Ford raise their Styrofoam cups.  This is an old joke between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's to you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... sucking my dick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughing away, Ford reaches for the envelope.  An unsmil- ing Johnny pulls it back and takes out a couple of bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No dessert until you've finished dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Packed with all the perks of his job, such as a car phone and a compact disc player, the interior of Ford's Fairlane is pretty jawdropping.  A FEEBLE WOMAN'S VOICE comes through the RADIO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny, why can't you play different kinds of music?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think the real question here, ma'am, is 'Are you wearing panties?'  A-a-a-h!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grisly SOUND EFFECT of a woman being sawed in half by a CHAINSAW comes over the RADIO.  An exasperated Ford turns it OFF with a remote control.  He grumbles, toward the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did I take it?  Because he's my friend.  But I never liked the bastard.  Why did I say yes?  Four thousand reasons.  Right, buddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The koala bear is revealed to be in the passenger seat, snugly behind a seat belt, patiently taking in Ford's complaints.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the chords of a corrosive ROCK-RAP TUNE, the VIEWER and Ford's Fairlane GLIDES BY various hot spots such as the Frolic Room, City Restaurant, and the Hard Rock Cafe with its embedded Cadillac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford weaves through the high-hair-headed crowd in front of the Roxy.  He shows Zuzu's picture to various shaking heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The corrosive song is now seen being belted out live by an all-black hard rock-rap outfit.  Ford can be seen offstage showing a roadie Zuzu's picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford breaks up a game of Lacrosse between some debauched British rockers and some nubile girls.  All are wearing Lacrosse helmets and holding Lacrosse equipment. The nubile girls take off their helmets.  The girls all seem to resemble Zuzu, but the real thing is not to be found.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford crosses a name from a list of bars, clubs, and concert halls rubber-banded to his visor, mumbling to his koala bear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are 5,000 private investigators in L.A.  It made sense to specialize.  Why did I pick the music industry?  Why not fishermen?  Fishermen get up, fish, sell the fish, then go to bed so they can get up and fish. How hard can the cases be:  'Ford, somebody switched the lures in my fucking tackle box.'  'Ford, my bait's been sabotaged.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford turns back ON his RADIO in disgruntlement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on radio) Well, it's time to sign off.  I know I get on the radio and say a lot of harsh things but I want you to know, deep down, I hate you, each and every one of you, so until tomorrow, burn in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GUNSHOT is heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my god, somebody just shot my engineer!  Oh, hey, they're doing something with my mike! Hey, I'm being electrocuted! And it hurts!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford pulls up to the radio station, chuckling at Johnny's histrionics.  He turns OFF the RADIO and gets out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford walks into the radio station still smiling at Johnny's screaming.  The lights in the radio station lobby are frantically blinking on and off.  Putting two and two together, Ford stops smiling.  He rushes to the reception desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call the police!  Johnny's being electrocuted!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, please.  He's just doing one of his little jokes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at the lights...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on speaker) Oh-fucking-shit-my-Christ-I'm- dying!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, he can't say 'oh-fucking- shit-my-Christ-I'm-dying' over the air!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford pushes past the guard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford bursts into the radio booth.  On the ground, with a bullet in his head, is the Engineer.  Ford crashes throug another set of doors and there, SPARKS EXPLODING out of h face and arms, is a sizzling, screaming Johnny Crunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cops, DETECTIVES and coroner flunkies zip back and forth with a dazed Ford acting as the eye of the hurricane, gravely contemplating the charred statue that was once his Brooklyn buddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I hope this guy signed your yearbook because it looks like your friendship, and your case, is closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An assistant pulls a burnt envelope from Johnny's body, filled with charred cash.  Ford watches in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'm going to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (patting Ford) Crying's good, Ford.  Crying's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commotion outside the booth becomes audible as the flashy obnoxious LT. AMOS makes an entrance.  He has made a horrible attempt at dressing stylish.  His tie is notably nasty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoh shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford looks away to the side of a console.  He sees a 45 rpm sleeve.  It is blank except for some handwriting; the name ART MOONEY, followed by a drawn star.  Ford quickly nabs it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd Mr. Rock 'n' Roll Detective boogie his way in here?  Anybody...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He discovered the body, Lt. Amos, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice tie, Lt. Anus, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think you're so hot just because you can get into any club. You think you're so hot, just because you have sex with great- looking women.  You think you're so hot just because you broke the Ensenada tape piracy ring...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta admit those are all pretty great reasons...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the fuck out of here, honey... What do we got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This guy was hated by everyone. He offended every race, religion, and sexual preference imaginable. He even said the Lakers suck. So basically we're looking at everyone from the Glendale Skinheads to Magic Johnson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford tries to ease out of the booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you running from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why shucks, Lt. Anus, you told me to get the fuck out of here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're hiding something... oh, oh, I'll have so much fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you hate me?  It's gotta be more than Me Private You, You Cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat) Two words.  Disco Express.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disco Ex -- man, that group sucked like a squid, they had some shitty single they wanted me to plug, back in my publicist days...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Booty Time.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and that lead singer, Jesus, that white Van McCoy wanna-be with the six-inch platform shoes. He looked...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was about to say he looked like shit, but hey, sure, he looked like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'It's booty time, it's booty time, across the U.S.A.  It's booty time...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were the lead sing -- Lieutenant, I didn't think anyone could cheer me up tonight... Thanks.  Really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A laughing Ford squeezes Lt. Amos's shoulder and walks away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A smoking Ford stands starkly, wailing with his guitar in cathartic quasi-Hendrixian blasts, ruining a perfectly nice MUSICAL SEGUE ON the SOUNDTRACK. He looks down to picture, nailed to the fence before him, of a young Ford and Johnny doing silly rock star poses. Young Ford holds a cheap guitar while Johnny clutches a pair of drumsticks. Ford presses the cigarette against the photo, setting it fire and then resumes his "playing."  The Kid rolls up on his skateboard, holding his ears, breaking into Ford's so

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ouch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you, get off my cloud.  I'm talking to my friend.  1962 Fender Stratocaster with original humbucking pick-ups, maple neck, strung upside down for a left- handed motherfucking genius... Jimi Hendrix.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who cares?  I got a case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve pack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid holds up a bunch of wadded-up money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This ain't no social call.  One hundred bucks.  To find my father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up to God) Did he just say what I think he said?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a clue.  Look at my ring. Before my old lady ran off to Baja, she told me my dad had this same ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid holds out his hand.  A ring of Snoopy in his fighter pilot outfit is attached to his hand.  A couple of notes of "Snoopy and the Red Baron" play on the soundtrack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy Colonel Mustard.  Gosh, you didn't mention the big clue... Kid, I can't take your money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need it that bad.

dialogues.speaker: INT. FORD'S PLACE
dialogues.text: Ford snores away on his couch, holding his guitar.  The koala bear sleeps beside him.  The DOORBELL RINGS.  And AGAIN.  Ford's eyes pop open to a pile of wadded up money on his coffee table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe it.  I took the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He meanders to the door like a Cocoon II cast member and opens the door.  COLLEEN SUTTON stands in a striking pose at the door.  Behind her in the street is a blue limousin and a driver. The very attractive Colleen belongs to the genre of rich people that has seen it all, every piece of decadence perpetuated.  Nothing fazes her, even the chilling sight of a just-woke-up Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford Fairlane, I'm Colleen Sutton and I need your help.  I have a problem and it pertains to the music industry.  What is it they call you?  Mr. Rock and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't say it.  Orange juice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford takes a carton of orange juice from the coffee table He shakes it and then pours into a pretty used-looking glass also from the coffee table.  He hands it to the deadpan Colleen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry about the glass.  And the house.  And the breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Fairlane, I'm very rich.  The kind of rich that warps minds. Nothing offends me.  When I was eleven, I walked in on my father and the Shetland pony he had given me for my tenth birthday. Does that excite you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, I never met your father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colleen looks down to Ford's crotch.  Ford does the same and then raises his head with a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that!  Don't take it personally. He always wakes up before I do. Down boy!  Roseanne Barr naked!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's your decorator?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some fag.  Charged me up the ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fag?  Ass?  I'm sorry, is that a joke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor taste.  I know.  Listen, I respect homosexuals.  When I was young, my maid was a homosexual. (after the silence) My maid was a homosexual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have a sense of humor, either.  Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Incredibly LOUD MUSIC BLASTS through the room.  Colleen splashes orange juice all over herself, undulating in a wacky, Martin Shortesque double take.  Ford remotes off his alarm.  Colleen regains her composure with a big orange juice stain. They sit upon the couch, the dozing koala between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that we've broken the ice...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need you to find my little sister. She goes by the name Zuzu...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zuzu Petals.  You want me to rescue her from the gorgeous hell that is L.A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But how did you know?  Here, take this picture...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colleen holds out the picture of Zuzu blowing a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks.  I carry my own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see, you're her worried sister.  Yesterday I met her worried father who incidentally was about five years younger than you. In fact, I capped off the evening by watching him get electrocuted. They talk about cases like this in the private eye handbook... something about a ten-foot pole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speechless, Colleen pulls out a thick envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five thousand should be enough to assuage any qualms you have about my family tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but of course for now, I only get a twenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, you may take it all now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... I have some questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no answers.  Thanks for the stain.  Find the girl.  In the envelope are tickets to the Dorothy Chandler.  We'll chat again, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford gives a glance to the table and the 45 sleeve with Art Mooney's name and the star on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, the Dorothy Chandler.  I was just there with my good friend Art Mooney the other night...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuthin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colleen makes a graceful exit.  Ford pauses to get his bearings then picks up his red hotline phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again decked out in an aggressively conservative business outfit, Jazz picks up the phone and breaks character.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: K-O-D-S is going to make me rich... Uh, Ford, aren't we frisky this morning.  It's only four o'clock. I guess the early bird gets wormed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford cuts her off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet.  Tell me you tapped in the police computer and found out lots of good stuff about Art Mooney...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found a lot of Art Mooneys. None with a police record, though. Not even Synchronicity.  Have you checked out Johnny Pinzolo/Crunch's houseboat yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford pours milk on a bowl of Fruit Loops for the now- awake koala bear, who fumbles a spoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight after I see Don. Some Beverly Hillbilly just hired me to find you-know-fucking-who. Name's Colleen Sutton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spooky.  I'll process her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling tickets from envelope) Cool.  Jazz, meet me at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion tonight. I'll have a ticket for you at the door.  Some concert.  Could be interesting.  Dress nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don Cleveland, the suave black producer from the club, si behind a large mixing board along with engineers and mixe A passable tune with ghoulish VOCALS is FILTERED into the booth.  As Don speaks, Ford stands behind him, staring through the glass at the source of the wretched music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't seen her around, and as for who would want to kill Johnny Crunch, line forms to the left. You'd find less people on our planet who wanted him alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a trance; to the glass) Great pipes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don laughs as the viewer gets a look at KYLE TROY, a very young pretty-boy whose non-singing is matched by his non-guitar-playing ability. A number of studio musicians valiantly try to make some- thing out of the song they're playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard cars fuck with more harmony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about it. Name's Kyle Troy.  Can't we bring up the bass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's up as far as it can go.  Any more tricks and we're not going to be able to hear his voice at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tempt me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could Grendel Records sign such a wick-prick?  I guess Julian Grendel really is deaf as a fucking doorknob.  I hear Ray Charles is going to head up the video division.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually that's rather an intriguing idea...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone' face drops.  Behind Ford stands the charis- matic JULIAN GRENDEL.  Julian laughs, allowing the others to do so.  He shakes Ford's hand, motioning to the mixing booth window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good to meet you, Mr. Fairlane. Your mouth makes quite a reflection.  I'm Julian Grendel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boing.  You're one hell of a lip reader.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (comically motioning down to his tie) Why thank you.  It's a Christmas present. (a beat) That was my sense of humor, everyone.  I wish you would fake a laugh.  It's easy with a deaf person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grendel mimics a vivid but silent belly-laugh.  Ford chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew your father.  He was quite...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An asshole?  A swine?  A ballistic turd?  Pick one. (with a laugh) I never knew what a blessing my accident was until he died and I had to take over the company.  You see the music is irrelevant in this industry.  I'm going to have to ship this 'wick-prick' platinum just so teenage girls can have a compact disc cover to get wet with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian's happy as long as he doesn't see glass shatter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (motioning to the yelping Kyle) I never thought I'd be jealous of your handicap... Sorry to hear about Bobby Vomit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrible thing, but good career move.  His record sales have gone way up.  I'll just have to create a new Black Vomit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just discussing this whole Vomit thing with my friend Art Mooney.  Do you know him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kyle finally finishes off his classic tune and gives the booth a thumbs-up sign and a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that asshole smiling about? (into a microphone) That was fantastic, man.  Let's just try it one more time. (clicking off microphone) Well, sorry, Ford, I couldn't help you.  Uh, Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford bursts through the door.  Everybody stops playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guys, guys, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yo, what's the hassle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're killing rock and raping roll.  Keith Richard's rolling in his grave and the poor bastard ain't even dead yet.  You're tearing me apart!  Rock 'n' roll is, is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford starts snapping his fingers -- looking around -- snap snap -- Kyle Troy frowns -- snap snap -- a couple of the band members nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a '65 Cadillac. (snap, snap) Spare time on the back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bass player jumps in -- BUM BUM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charge cord to Goldblatts. (snap, snap) But I ain't got you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kyle pouts -- the drummer kicks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got women to the right of me... I got women to the left of me... I got chicks all around me... But I ain't got you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rhythm guitarist and keyboardist join the jam.  The band is heating up -- playing louder -- Don and the boys in the booth are bopping their heads to the beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta a pocket full of crumpled bills, I gotta stomach full of different pills, I got Fanny Fox and Wilba Mills, But I ain't got you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The band suddenly kicks into a rousing instrumental break of Calvin Carter's "I Ain't Got You."  Ford gets wicked with the mike stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I ain't got you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I ain't got you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I ain't got you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I ain't got you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, I ain't got you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, I ain't got you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't -- got -- you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- And with a quick wave, everyone cuts off.  Ford turns to a very put-off Kyle Troy and grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, that's entertainment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford whisks through -- nods to Don:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a copy of that sent to me, will ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right away!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don cracks up as Ford makes his exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pleased-with-himself Ford bounds from his studio.  He comes across an eerie sight in the hallway -- Two men in GUNSLINGER coats over Armani suits.  One is a black mohaw PUNK and the other is a highhairheaded HEAVY METALER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys part of a band?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (contemptuously amused) ... Sure.  Our name is Pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford fakes a smile.  The duo snort and sneer as he walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford's Fairlane pulls up before a pretty ominous marina. Boars are eerily moored with no sign of human beings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford creeps across the pier.  He puts the finishing touches on his arm-to-hand sliding gun apparatus before looking to a nice-sized but inherently tacky boat from which an eerie ROCK SONG spookily emits.  The bow reads: THE MIGHTY PENIS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder which boat's Johnny's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford comes onto the deck of Mighty Penis.  He glances around before descending below to follow the siren call of the eerie MUSIC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford comes down and turns on some bizarrely hued lights revealing a literally rocking bachelor pad from hell com- plete with a scary rack of dildos and an inflatable doll that floats above a neon ME sign.  Ford goes past a wall that has cut out quasi-nude shots of breasts and buttocks

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The love boat is making another run...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He then makes a glance to another picture on the wall. It is the same young-and-wanna-be-rock-stars picture of Johnny and Ford that Ford viewed earlier. Ford sadly blinks before looking to a gun rack on the wall that holds three shotguns.  Ford wobbles over to an entertainment system set up next to the rack.  He turns OFF the eerie rocker on the STEREO.  A video cassette marked "Collie and Me" lies on an adjoining VCR.  Ford puts the tape in.

dialogues.speaker: TAPE
dialogues.text: The TAPE WHIRS on to show Johnny kneeling on his heart- shaped bed in a comical schoolboy outfit and a dunce cap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on video) Where's my Queen Collie?  I need some order!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colleen Sutton comes on the screen in killer black lin- gerie and wearing a paper Burger King crown.  She steps threateningly toward the bed, carrying a scepter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on video) Queen Collie is here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford snaps OFF the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is why I have cable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford steps over to a closet and opens the door.  And there's a smiling guy in a psychedelic tie-dye shirt standing inside.  Ford quickly closes the door -- and BAM -- a hand crashes through the door and latches on to Ford's neck.  Ford beats off the arm. Ka-blam!  The smiling guy kicks the door off its hinges. Meet SMILEY:  He's muscular, and seems mean, despite the fact he has a ponytail, wears sandals, nice black gloves, and has a damn smile that never ever leaves his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smiley's fist swooshes at Ford's head.  Ford's hand whips out of nowhere and grabs the fist in midair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're ten seconds away from the most embarrass --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crunch!  Smiley punches Ford across the jaw with his left Ford's body careens into a dresser.  He bolts up and as he did so wow-ly in his opening scene, super-swiftly rais his arm.  Only this time the gun doesn't slide out. Ford feebly tries to reach in his sleeve to retrieve the gun but crack!  Smiley strikes again.  Ford runs to the gun rack and tries to pull out a shotgun, but it is locke Panicked, Ford yanks the entire gun rack off the wall as Smiley latches on with a nasty bear hug.  Ford FIRES off wild BLAST from one of the still-in-the-rack GUNS. The shotgun blast demolishes a Playboy centerfold and causes a BLAST of WATER to whoosh out from her remains. Smiley moves into a strangling mode while Ford's hands move down to the next gun on the rack.  Another BLAST BURSTS a hole in the other WALL. Ford FIRES OFF yet another one into the floor below him causing a devastating geyser that allows him to break away from Smiley. Water is amusingly blasting out from every angle.  Ford and Smiley battle semi-obliviously to this new added element of nature.  The water rises above their knees. Ford spins around and grabs the TV off the still-standing home entertainment center.  He SMASHES it upon Smiley's head, submerging him into the water which is now at Ford's waist.  Ford frantically scans the water like a shark attack victim, but Smiley does not emerge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marco...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford quickly wades to the stairs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is sinking pretty fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford collapses onto the damp deck with a gasp.  The entire lower level of the boat is underwater.  Ford works himself into a standing position as Smiley ferociously resurrects from out of decktop windowcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Polo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever you're getting paid, I can give you twenty, maybe thirty bucks more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smiley does a savage medley of punches across Ford's gut before slapping him into the deck rail.  WATER SPLASHES onto the deck as the boat goes into death throes.  Ford ungracefully makes a clinging jump onto...

dialogues.speaker: FLY BRIDGE
dialogues.text: Ford beaches himself on the tippy top of the boat. Smiley effortlessly pops up and moves around behind Ford's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had enough?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smiley laughs as he places his thumb behind Ford's earlob at Ford's jawline.  This hurts... The fly bridge is the only part of the boat above water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feel my thumb?  I keep it there forty seconds more and a welt develops cutting off the oxygen to your brain.  I leave.  Twenty- one minutes later, you're dead. The slowest, most painful minutes a person can experience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you never saw 'A Very Brady Christmas.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (squeezing tighter) Case closed, okay?  Thirty seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's fine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm off it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off what?  Twenty seconds...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The case!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.  One more thing.  This is personal.  I want you to tell me you're a big sissy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I.  Am.  The.  Biggest.  Sissy. In.  The.  Whole.  Fucking.  World.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smiley removes his thumb, pats Ford on the head, and then proceeds to exuberantly backstroke away.  A job well done Ford's torso is the only thing above water.  His sliding gun apparatus pings to life.  The gun finally slides into his hand.  Ford snorts and shakes his head as he dis- appears below the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elite of Los Angeles, with impeccable tuxedoes and gowns to prove it, grandly stream into a large auditorium. Ford, holding a plastic bag of party ice over his face, stumbles through the pavilion doors in a wrinkled tuxedo. The ice bag breaks, sending ice and water down Ford's shirt.  Various snooty patrons turn to harrumph, includ- ing Colleen, who does a double take when she realizes who she is harrumphing at.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God, Mr. Fairlane, you look like the Fall of Saigon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colleen and Johnny, sitting in a tree, k-i-s-s-i-n-g...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, let's go sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of gasps rise up out of the patrons around them. Ford and Colleen feel the breeze of heads turning all around them.  They turn to see what everybody is looking at. What they are looking at is Jazz!  Gone are her glasses and businesslike dress.  She stands at the inside entrance of the pavilion in a tight, low-at-the-top- high-at-the-bottom black leather mini-dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (catching his breath) Excuse me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jazz squints at the crowd trying to find Ford, who is quickly coming right towards her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Jazz, I told you to dress 'nice' not nice.  What, did you think this was a date?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford looks to Jazz's grim face.  Yes, that's what she thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Jazz.  After this, I'll throw a burger down your throat, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a fucking gentleman.  What do you want from me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This Colleen Sutton woman I'm with. If she flees me to go powder her whatever, I need you to keep tabs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford, they're starting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colleen strolls back from where she came.  Ford back- pedals to catch up with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You going to be okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, 'they're stahting.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Male dancers wearing incredibly tight outfits that leave nothing to the imagination prance and move across the stage. Ford and Colleen take in the spectacle before them.  They speak in whispers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you know about Johnny Crunch and myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking to the dancers) I'm sorry, that's gotta be a pair of tube socks he has down there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in back) Shh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want off the case, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: BALLERINA
dialogues.text: with absurdly graphic nipples pirouettes. Ford mimes his eye being poked out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ouch... Of course I want off the case.  Some monster from Woodstock tried and succeeded in killing me tonight.  The fact I'm alive's a technicality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Queen Collie, I have a code. I never, ever, drop a case.  Besides, I, uh, used all your money to pay my bills, so I kinda owe you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonsense.  After what you've been through, it sounds like I owe you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to stage) They did one of these about my ex- wife.  It's called 'The Nutcracker.' (after the silence; enunciating) 'The Nut-crack-er'... I don't need money.  I need some questions answered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do my best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Question one:  Can I have some money?  Kidding.  Why didn't you tell me about you and Johnny?  You two were into something even more dangerous than sex, weren't you? Who?  What?  Where?  How?  Now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colleen looks out to the two Armani Gunslingers, Punk and Metal, looming by the exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonathan was such a beautiful man. No one knew him like I did... Excuse me.  I can't do this now. I'll call you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for the information. Appreciate it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colleen mock-whimpers into the aisle.  Ford turns to a di nified woman seated next to him and motions to the stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That guy gets an erection, he gives himself a black eye.  I mean, you can see him coming around a corner and still have time to comb your hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you please be quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll be telling that joke tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dignified woman laughs and Ford smiles at her laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colleen strides out of the auditorium and purposefully veers down the hall, into the ladies' room. From a seated position at the other end of the hall, Jazz frenetically pops up and pushes on her glasses.  She clac after Colleen, into the ladies' room as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Balletgoers stream into the lobby for the post-ballet re- ception.  Ford meanders out with the buzzing crowd, a couple patrons taking notice of his wrinkled attire.  For blazes a Marlboro Gold as a SNOOTY NON-SMOKER who got a snide closeup earlier in the segment, points to a "Yes, I mind if you smoke" button on his lapel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you read... 'smoker'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you whistle 'Man in the Mirror' out your ass... 'snapperhead'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, don't be a pottymouth.  I just don't want cancer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ford speaks, he takes a rubberband and attaches it to a lighter in a way that keeps the flame lit.  He then places it in the Non-Smoker's tuxedo pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, you're right, sir, and I'm sorry.  I thought I lived in a country where you were free to do any stupid thing you wanted; drive to work naked, make love to a V.C.R., but hey, you reminded me I live in a hell where any sperm like you can stab me in the heart with these things called opinions, just because you have them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Non-Smoker weakly smiles, his jacket starting to smok

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay.  It's okay, guy.  Smoke all you want.  Here, have one of mine...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Non-Smoker fumbles out a pack of cigarettes from his literally smoking jacket and then bolts away. An hors d'oeuvres tray cruises by.  Ford grabs something on a toothpick and casually shoves possibly the worst thing he's ever tasted in his life into his mouth.  Ford doesn't chew -- he just looks around for someplace to spit it out just as Julian Grendel approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, hello, Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmmmmm.  Mmmm, mmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must say you're an island of reality in an ocean of diarrhea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jazz excitedly approaches Ford and Grendel.  Ford grabs her and deeply kisses her.  Ford pulls back and addresses Jack in his normal voice.  Meanwhile, Jazz's face turns color, her mouth trying to deal with the most disgusting transferal of an hors d'oeuvre in film history.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's good to see you, Julian. This is my assistant, Jazz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmmmmm.  Mmmm, mmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what did you think of the ballet? Was it like a warm Ice Capades?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) Yeah, I did, you condescending fuck, but I miss Snoopy coming out at the end.  Isn't your enjoyment impaired?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry I can run every ballet note for note in my brain...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jazz swallows, her eyes bulging with delicate agony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, were you one of those brilliant child prahdigies who was writing baroque operas while the other kids were fingerpainting Mr. Greenjeans...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian winces in pain, and then smiles...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something like that... Let's talk business.  I think someone is trying to rip my company off. I've tried the Yellow Pages, now I think it's your turn...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with Linda Blair's Exorcist voice) If you'll excuse us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jazz, we're talking here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, another time, another place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grendel watches the couple walk off and the viewer hears the CLASSICAL MUSIC in his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jazz pulls Ford into the cool of the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you interrupt?  Maxwell seemed like he wanted to hire me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, goodies from the ice queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jazz pulls from her pockets a small toy duck, a Baby Ruth bar, and a compact disc reading "Black Vomit's Greatest Spits."  It has a red number two on the cover.  Ford take the stuff from her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you get this from her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want to know, believe me. But don't worry, I washed my hands...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fucking C.D.  Wow, this case is closed.  So, she's got bad taste in music and in men... Did I tell you she and Johnny were lovers and that they were into something and he got killed for it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing at his bald exposition) No, as a matter of fact you didn't. What about the girl, Zuzu Petals, how does she fit in?  I mean, she is what this case is about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I knew.  You did good work...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make eye contact when you say that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, that dress.  What do you say we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celebrate?  Like we celebrated after solving the White Bluesman murders?  Forget it, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford and Jazz stroll to their respective cars parked side-by-side.  Jazz drives a black Volkswagen bug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... Hey, how about that hors d'oeuvre, tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jazz cackles and gets in her car.  Ford watches her go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In his underwear, Ford vegges on his couch with a koala bear at his feet and with a BLENDER WHIRRING beside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't I pick fishermen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford STOPS the BLENDER, flips off the lid, and begins drinking his homemade vodka milkshake straight out of the blender, but only after setting it on fire and blowing it out. Ford then lazily remotes ON the TELEVISION.  "MTV News" with KURT LODER finishes up.  Ford unslumps up with Kurt's revelations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on TV) Police are now saying Bobby Vomit was not the victim of an overdose as first suspected, but was actually poisoned.
