dialogues.text: When I was young, I read Billboard and I could not believe how much Grendel Records and how little of it my idiot father Old Jack Grendel got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's pretty amazing how much cash you gotta give to the actual artists who create the music.  Those ingrates really take a bite.  But seriously, when Pops died, you got Vomit, Crunch, and Sutton to help finance a C.D. Cleans operation. You got greedy and they tried to get the three discs together to threaten you, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this, are you holding a microphone behind my head?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holding the radio mike, Zuzu scampers up behind Grendel with giddy self-consciousness at the adventure at hand. As Grendel launches into a tirade, Zuzu holds up the mike just behind him. She reacts to his words with over- the-top facial expressions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should kill more music people! When I was sixteen, I wrote an opera, the greatest piece of music ever created in the 20th Century outside the Dirty Dancing soundtrack.  It was called 'Paco the Shoeshine Boy.'  When I showed it to my father, he said it 'wasn't happening.'  That 'no playlists worth his while would touch it'!

dialogues.speaker: CLUB
dialogues.text: The crowd rumbles into silence to listen in shock to Grendel's words coming over the loudspeaker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's face it, making money is the only art form open to innovation. Whoever says they're in the business because they like music is a lying pathetic piece of shit or total idiot like Kyle Troy...

dialogues.speaker: STAGE
dialogues.text: A tear streams down Kyle's face.

dialogues.speaker: OFFSTAGE
dialogues.text: Grendel continues to dig his own grave with Zuzu having a ball in the b.g., exploiting his deafness with commentary

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this guy flucked up or what? I think he's going to blow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The day my father turned down 'Paco' I dedicated my life to taking over this fucking industry and making it so disgusting, so sleazy, and so corrupt that it would have to self-destruct!  I even pissed in the punchbowl tonight...

dialogues.speaker: CLUB
dialogues.text: A line of industry types by the punch bowl, simultan- eously spit outward. An amused eyepatchless Jazz, Sam in tow, passes them on their way to the bar.  Seeing Jazz, the bartender pulls out a fountain glass in order to make a vodka milkshake.

dialogues.speaker: BACKSTAGE
dialogues.text: Ford is actually concerned about the frothing Grendel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, Julian, that accident took away more than your hearing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Accident?  Accident!  You naive pussball, when I realized my life of music could only be a life of music industry.  I cut my fucking ears off so I'd only hear my music. Here, look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grendel pulls off his plastic ears and holds them out to Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoh graphic!  I'm going to dream of ears for a year!  Ugh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just be thankful he wasn't dissatisfied with his sex life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Zuzu-directed comment causes Grendel to wield around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You little bitch...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (guilelessly into the mike) 'Feelings, whoa oh, feelings...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grendel loses it.  The inner CLASSICAL MUSIC in his head comes ON the SOUNDTRACK playing ten times faster than normal. Zuzu, with a squeal, runs off to the stage.  Grendel pursues...

dialogues.speaker: STAGE
dialogues.text: Zuzu and Grendel run out in view of everyone.  Grendel looks out at the dead silent tableau of people who were cheering him only moments before. The crowd starts to boo... Ford walks out onstage, having a hard time keeping down a grin.  Grendel suddenly yanks a gun from the security guard and points it at Ford, who stops smiling.  Kyle Troy faints.

dialogues.speaker: BAR
dialogues.text: The bartender puts a last blast of vodka atop the shake and is right about to light it on fire, but Sam grabs and throws...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jazz!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jazz catches it and she throws the shake up to the stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford grabs the shake and flings the contents into Grendel who gets off a SHOT with his GUN.  Ford dives behind an amp as Julian lets another SHOT FLY.  Ford pulls from his pockets matchbooks from a multitude of L.A. clubs.  He lights a handful of them on fire as Grendel moves in for the kill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm still the king!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (popping up) Julian, you're fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford flings his homemade fireball into Grendel's vodka doused tux.  He explodes in flames, staggering around the stage.

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: Jaime and Larry watch in bemused detachment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this for real, Larry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way, Jaime.  He's wearing this gooey stuff on his body that the flames can't affect.  Bobby Vomit opened his act this way.

dialogues.speaker: STAGE
dialogues.text: The flaming Grendel stumbles to an electronic keyboard set and begins playing a warped piano solo.  The KEY- BOARDS spark and churn amid the flames before grandly EXPLODING along with Julian Grendel.  The sprinkler syste blasts on.

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: A deadpan Larry turns to a jaw-dropped Jaime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that... I have no idea...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford bounds off the stage.  He is oblivious to the sprinkler system-induced rain.  Don greets him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for the promotion, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No prob...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jazz romantically moves through the makeshift rain.  Ford strides to her when Zuzu sprouts up holding hands with a beefy rock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look who I found.  It's Damion Flemm!  He's taking me on tour to Japan!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford laughs, almost fatherly, then asks the question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Zuzu.  Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Ford.  I'm okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zuzu tenderly kisses him. Seeing this, Jazz glumly droops her head and turns around heading back out the club entrance.  She passes an enter- ing Lt. Amos and detective.  Lt. Amos is wearing the infamous white John Travolta Saturday Night Fever ensemble, with gold chains. The sprinkler system has gone off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do realize that tonight is disco appreciation night at the Coconut Teazer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, sir, but we got a report that Fairlane and the psycho- killer-groupie are here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There they are!  Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford and Zuzu turn to Amos with "Oh brother" expressions. They walk toward him with smiling faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should've known you two were in this together...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zuzu drops to her knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, sexual favors won't help...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zuzu slams Amos in the groin, sending him to his knees. Ford shoves the CDs in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy listening...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford looks for Jazz all around him with a confused expres sion.  The Ovaries approach, two of them have their arms wrapped around Sam the ex-sleazebag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've learned my lesson, Ford. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't he the best?  Why don't you come out with us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't.  Have you seen my assistant, Jazz?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She took off.  Said something about you being a real asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford glumly droops his head and shuffles away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An RTD BUS RUMBLES to the corner of Ford's street.  The sad Detective shuffles off the bus to the tune of the SADDEST SONG in film history. As Ford walks toward his house, he passes his debris, still splayed out on the street from the night before; mangled gold records, smoldered speakers, his red hotline now burntline phone, and then there's that funky sliding- arm-and-gun apparatus with a gun attached.  Ford picks it up, sliding the gun back and forth with a rueful smile. Ford's house is looking gloomy, dark, and missing a lot of pieces.  Ford walks through the intact, but dis- embodied, front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Head still drooping, Ford closes the door behind him. A CLICK causes him to look up.  Sitting atop a battered piece of couch, blood stains neatly blended into his tie- dye shirt, is Smiley holding a gun.  Cheerful as always.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta be kidding!  This is unfuckingbelievable!  I have to start the evening crawling down Capital Records, I shoulda chose suicide then, but oh no, the night was young!  Next up, my guitar! The second most important thing I own and now it's toothpicks for the homeless on Hollywood Boulevard!  Then, then, after I burned up your brother, Jazz... I should say as a fucking footnote I've usually treated women like shit -- used corsages, the wet spot, you know giving out Domino's Pizza's phone number and saying  it's mine... Tonight was different. I felt respect.  I felt love.  Then Jazz left me... and now I get to die!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The point?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me go out like a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tossing away his gun) Anyway you want it, asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford super-swiftly raises his arm and Ta-daah!  The gun slides smoothly down his arm into his hand.  Smiley, for the first time in our story, stops smiling.  Ford FIRES a cute hole in his forehead, sending him crashing into a wa that was barely standing to begin with.  It crumbles down

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to his arm) Thanks for working. (to Smiley) Thanks for being a hu-uge bonehead. 'Let me go out like a man' -- Ha!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford emerges from the more disembodied than ever front door.  The Kid stands before him, on the front lawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, did you find my dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I got some good news and some bad news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, go on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good news is that yeah, I found him.  The bad news is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford raises his hand.  He is wearing the Snoopy the Fighter Pilot ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of sentimental bullshit is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I love you, too, you little jerk.  Jesus, guy tries to make a commitment and he's gotta eat shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's my real father, man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He, he, lives in South America... he's doing that anthropologist- archeologist-dentist kind of thing ... he's real busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid starts to sob.  Ford reaches out and grabs his hand.  Their Snoopy rings touch. The two tough guys walk down the street together, holding hands.  The viewer's VIEWPOINT HANGS BACK, allowing them some privacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need someone to help me with my case load, you interested?  This whole father/son thing, if you're not into it, I mean, it's okay. You know what I'm saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut the heck up... Pop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Jazz's VOLKSWAGEN SCREECHES before the pair. The viewer's VIEWPOINT QUICKLY GOES TO the action as Jazz jettisons from her car, holding out some keys...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just can't deal with all this crap between us, I'm sorry.  I'm quitting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get hitched.  I guess I, you know, love you.  It's a beautiful thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wha --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moment is broken by a RINGING PHONE.  Ford shushes Jazz with his finger and then backtracks to his burnt- ridiculously-still-working, hotline phone.  He picks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: K-O-D-S is going to make me rich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The viewer's VIEWPOINT is LULLED TO a friendly hut by a beautiful tropical cove.  A humble hand-drawn sign reads: FORD FAIRLANE, PRIVATE INVESTIGATOR - FISHERMEN ONLY. SWINGING AROUND the hut, the viewer DISCERNS Ford, Jazz, and The Kid kicking back on chaise lounges in silly tropical shirts with identical sunglasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love the music industry, especially the tacky radio giveaway part...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The viewer's VIEWPOINT PANS OVER a bit to reveal, sitting next to The Kid on a very small chaise lounge and in a very small leather jacket is the koala bear with a sweet little neck brace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wha-at.  You didn't really think we'd kill the flucking koala bear, did you?
